paragraphs.text: So, if you’re not learning, you’re not living.
paragraphs.name: d543

paragraphs.text: So listen-up, kids (and everybody else). Forget about “too old” to learn to code, because it’s never too late. Clunky beginners are cool!
paragraphs.name: ecf3

paragraphs.text: 3. Making stuff is the real learning. The hard part is the valuable part. The goal is learning enough to create the evidence that you can — and will — get paid to make good stuff every day. So, do that now.
paragraphs.name: 34d5

paragraphs.text: 5. You contribute to diversity.
paragraphs.name: 3d47

paragraphs.text: Really appreciate this article!
paragraphs.name: d57a

paragraphs.text: Thanks for writing this.
paragraphs.name: ca7d

paragraphs.text: I am a 36 year old mum of three homeschooling kids, and I am learning to code alongside my 15 and 12 year old kids through free code camp and python courses from Coursera. I think I am learning a lot faster and enjoying it more than when I took a few high school coding classes back when I was young.

paragraphs.text: Thanks for this. The first time I logged into the Internet, I was 25 and tutored by my then 54 year old father. I’m now closing on 48 and learning information design by a team whose ages range between 23 and 61.
paragraphs.name: e029

paragraphs.text: When you humble yourself before the knowledgeable, and don’t care how old or young they are, you’re forever young.
paragraphs.name: 4db5

26b6aa6dbfa.title: I hear this question all the time, and I applaud you for taking this head-on.

paragraphs.text: I hear this question all the time, and I applaud you for taking this head-on.
paragraphs.name: f65a

paragraphs.text: When it comes to learning new skills — like coding — people commonly under-estimate the value of life experience, and over-estimate the negative effects associated with the aging brain.
paragraphs.name: ec2e

7fea15cde01a.title: Surprised this not the top highlighted paragraph.

paragraphs.text: Surprised this not the top highlighted paragraph. Change is constant. It doesn’t matter what industry, what profession, what part of life you are living — CHANGE will happen — and it’s happening faster every day.
paragraphs.name: e498

paragraphs.text: There is only one thing you can do as a counter balance to change — and that’s LEARN. It’s not a meme, it’s not a…

paragraphs.text: One addition to your list:
paragraphs.name: b647

paragraphs.text: At a certain age, you fully understand and appreciate a simple fact of life … nothing is forever, everything has an expiration date.
paragraphs.name: f9c7

58e926799af4.title: I am [enter your age here]. Is that too late to become a developer?

paragraphs.text: I am [enter your age here]. Is that too late to become a developer?
paragraphs.name: b4e2

virtuals.subtitle: There’s a popular meme going around the developer boot-camp world: “I’m an unborn child. Is that too old to start learning to code?”

content.subtitle: There’s a popular meme going around the developer boot-camp world: “I’m an unborn child. Is that too old to start learning to code?”

paragraphs.text: Love your article! Two years ago I completed a 9 week coding bootcamp and learned to code. I was 55 at the time and the oldest by 20 to 30 years. Since then, two persons from my Wyncode coding bootcamp community have joined my startup. Taking the plunge to be with and work with younger, more talented coders has been one of the best decisions of my life.

779f28839cc8.title: Everyone and everything has a starting point.

paragraphs.text: Everyone and everything has a starting point. And it’s never how you start, it how you end that matters.
paragraphs.name: 4d1c

paragraphs.text: If you need real world evidence — just look at the box scores for any sports team — you win or lose by the final score.
paragraphs.name: fa55

virtuals.subtitle: If you need real world evidence — just look at the box scores for any sports team — you win or lose by the final score.

content.subtitle: If you need real world evidence — just look at the box scores for any sports team — you win or lose by the final score.

paragraphs.text: Hi Chuck. Kudos! As a 54 year old who is “re-learning” to code, I enjoyed your article a lot. I have also seen this question frequently on the web lately and wonder why people think that only a young person can learn programming. It’s nice to see you sharing your thoughts on the matter and I couldn’t agree more!

eef26a187bc0.title: Thank you that was very encouraging

paragraphs.text: Thank you that was very encouraging
paragraphs.name: 09f0

43cf805a16bc.title: No way to a thumbs up icon here.

paragraphs.text: No way to a thumbs up icon here. learning through lessons is great, it gives you a basis. But doing it on a live project is like the mortar between the bricks — it gives those lessons something to hold onto.
paragraphs.name: d021

paragraphs.text: Loved this post! I’ll be sharing it with our followers over on Twitter — more people need to read this :)
